questions.question: The patient's blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Four different sphygmomanometers measure his BP, each with 3 readings. Match the sphygmomanometers with their respective accuracy and precision parameters. Sphygmomanometer readings Accuracy and Precision parameters 1. 120/80, 120/80, 120/80 a. Precise but inaccurate 2. 140/96, 108/62, 96/82 b. Imprecise but accurate 3. 140/96, 140/96, 140/96 c. Precise and accurate 4. 122/82, 120/80, 118/78 d. Imprecise and inaccurate
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b Explanation: A game of darts can help one understand precision and accuracy. Let the centre point be the true value or gold standard value. Accuracy: Closeness to true value. Precision: Findings are replicable. Accurate & precise Not accurate & precise Accurate & not precise Not accurate & not precise Every line hits the central point exactly at the gold standard value. The same finding is seen, but far from the true value; it is inaccurate. It is accurate as the result is closer to the true value in the first circle; it is not precise. It is not precise or accurate. Correct Matching: 120/80, 120/80, 120/80 - c) Precise and accurate. This set of readings consistently measures 120/80 mm Hg, indicating both precision (reproducibility of measurements) and accuracy (close to the true value). 140/96, 108/62, 96/82 - d) Imprecise and inaccurate. These readings vary significantly (140/96, 108/62, 96/82), indicating both lack of precision (inconsistent measurements) and accuracy (not close to the true value). 140/96, 140/96, 140/96 - a) Precise but inaccurate. Readings are consistent (140/96 each time), indicating precision (reproducibility) but they are consistently incorrect, hence inaccurate. 122/82, 120/80, 118/78 - b) Imprecise but accurate. The readings vary slightly (122/82, 120/80, 118/78), indicating lack of precision (slightly inconsistent measurements), but they are close to the true value (accurate).

questions.question: All comprise inherent properties of a screening test except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Yield Explanation: Yield is not one of the inherent properties of a screening test. Yield is defined as the number of new cases detected due to a screening test. It can be increased by restricting the sample size to high-risk groups, e.g., the presence of cardiovascular diseases in those who smoke. Disadvantage: identifying a small high-risk group can be difficult since some diseases might need a tedious filtration process to identify the high-risk population. Inherent properties of a screening test: Predictive accuracy Negative predictive value (Option A). Positive predictive value (Option D). Accuracy (Option B) - sensitivity & specificity. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 156 https://www.bmj.com/about-bmj/resources-readers/publications/epidemiology-uninitiated/10-screening

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain and the doctor suspects myocardial infraction thus orders a blood test to evaluate for a specific cardiac marker for the same which has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 90%. In the general population, the prevalence of acute myocardial infarction is 2%, while in patients presenting to the emergency department with chest pain, the prevalence increases to 30%. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is true concerning the test?

options.A: Positive predictive value remains constant when prevalence <25%
options.B: Negative predictive value increases as prevalence increases
options.C: Positive predictive value is directly proportional to the prevalence
options.D: Negative predictive value remains constant when prevalence >75%

questions.explanation: Correct ANSWER: C) Positive predictive value is directly proportional to the prevalence detects, i.e., PPV increases as the prevalence increases provided the sensitivity and specificity of the test remains unchanged over the course of time (since prevalence can be considered as the pre-test probability of a disease) Example: Total population of a town is 2000. Prevalence of a disease at three different time periods are 10,20 and 30% based on a definitive investigation. Sensitivity and specificity of a new test are 40% & 70% respectively Since the sensitivity & specificity are going to be considered as constants throughout, the number of true positives and hence the positive predictive values will increase proportionately to the given prevalences over these three different time periods. Reference: Park’s textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 156

questions.question: Among the population of 5 million people in a city, 1 in every 200 undergoes sudden cardiac arrest each year. A new government formed recently wanted to know the total number of sudden cardiac arrests in this population during the last 5 years. What will be the estimate per million population?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 25000 Explanation: The question asks about the occurrence of an event over a defined period of time, called “prevalence.” Prevalence is the total number of cases (old & new) documented over a specific period. It can interchangeably be used with the term “point prevalence.” Incidence can be defined as the total number of new cases which occur over a specified point in time. Prevalence = Incidence x Duration In the above example, Incidence = 1 in every 200 people = 5000 per million = 25000 in total every year Duration = 5 years. Hence, prevalence = 1,25,000 in 5 million people = 25000 per million over the last 5 years. Prevalence can also be derived from the formula below: Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 69

questions.question: In a population of 1000 people who are at high risk of contracting syphilis, 650 were confirmed to be positive by serological studies. A new test that acts by detecting a new biomarker "X" has been introduced and 600 were found to be positive among serology-positive patients. 120 out of the remaining 350 people were also found to be having “X”. What is the positive predictive value of this new test?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 83% Explanation: The positive predictive value of a test reflects the ratio of patients who actually have the disease to those who had positive test results. From the data given above, Serology positive Serology negative "X" positive 600 (a-true positive) 120 (b-false positive) "X" negative 50 (c-false negative) 230 (d-true negative) Positive predictive value = a/a+b = 600/600+120 = 83% The negative predictive value of a test reflects the probability that it will be negative in healthy, non-diseased individuals. In the above example, Negative predictive value = d/c+d = 230/230+50 = 82% Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 156

questions.question: A new imaging test has been introduced to diagnose breast cancer in a sample of 1500 people. Among those 600 people who have biopsy-confirmed breast carcinoma, 480 were found to be positive. 60 were also found positive among the remaining 900 biopsy-negative people. What is the sensitivity and specificity of this new test, respectively?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 80%; 93% Explanation: The sensitivity of a test is defined as its ability to detect the presence of a disease in truly diseased people (true positives). The specificity of a test is defined as its ability to exclude the presence of a disease in healthy, non-diseased people (true negatives). From the data given above, Biopsy positive Biopsy negative BRight positive 480 (a- true positive) 60 (b- false positive) BRight negative 120 (c- false negative) 840 (d- true negative) Sensitivity = a/a+c = 480/480+120 = 80% Specificity = d/b+d = 840/840+60 = 93% Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th edition, page : 155

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Cronbach's alpha?

options.A: Cronbach's alpha is a measure of internal consistency reliability.
options.B: It ranges from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating greater reliability.
options.C: Cronbach's alpha can be used to assess the validity of a measurement instrument.
options.D: Cronbach's alpha assumes that all items in the scale measure the same underlying construct.

questions.explanation: instrument. CORRECT ANSWER: C) Cronbach's alpha can be used to assess the validity of a measurement instrument. Explanation: Cronbach's alpha is a measure of internal consistency reliability, not validity. Cronbach’s alpha: It measures the internal consistency of a test or scale, indicating the extent to which all items measure the same concept or construct. Alpha ranges between 0 and 1; higher values indicate greater internal consistency. To ensure validity, it should be calculated before a test is used. Reliability interpretation: Alpha reflects the measurement error in a test; higher alpha indicates less error variance. Recommended Values: Acceptable alpha values typically range from 0.70 to 0.95; extremely high values may indicate redundant items. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4205511/

questions.question: Sensitivity/(1-specificity) is the formula to find which among the following?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: A) Positive likelihood ratio Explanation: Positive likelihood ratio = Sensitivity/(1-specificity). Negative likelihood ratio = (1-sensitivity)/specificity. Likelihood ratios (LRs) compare the probability of a particular test result in people with the disease to the probability of the same result in people without the disease. Interpretation: LR of 1.0 means the test result is equally likely in those with and without the disease (no discrimination). Positive likelihood ratio Negative likelihood ratio It represents how much more likely a positive test result is in individuals with the disease than those without it. LR+ > 1 indicates a positive test result is more likely in those with the disease. Higher LR+ values (>10) indicate strong evidence of disease. Indicates how much less likely a negative test result is in individuals with the disease compared to those without the disease. LR- < 1 indicates a negative test result is less likely in those with the disease. Lower LR- values (<0.1) suggest strong evidence for excluding the disease. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5950618/#:~:text=LIKELIHOOD%20RATIOS,-Likeliho od%20ratios%20compare&text=LR%2B%20%3D%20Probability%20that%20a%20person,without%20the%20dise ase%20tested%20positive.&text=LR%E2%88%92%20%3D%20Probability%20that%20a%20person,without%20th e%20disease%20tested%20negative .

questions.question: What purpose is Kaplan-Meier analysis used primarily for?

options.A: Assessing the impact of economic factors on survival rates.
options.B: Estimating the probability of survival over time.
options.C: Analysing the correlation between lifestyle choices and health outcomes.
options.D: Predicting future trends in population demographics.

questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER : B) Estimating the probability of survival over time. Explanation: Kaplan-Meier estimate is used to calculate the probability of survival over time after a certain treatment or intervention. It's particularly useful in clinical trials and community trials to assess the effect of interventions on survival outcomes. Censored Observations: These are the situations when subjects do not experience the event of interest (e.g., death) before the study ends or are lost to follow-up. Advantages: Handles censored data effectively, accommodating subjects who do not experience the event of interest during the study period. Provides a clear visual representation of survival probabilities over time. Clinical Relevance: Widely used in clinical research to evaluate treatment efficacy and compare interventions based on survival outcomes. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3059453/

questions.question: Given below are a few statements regarding the receiver operating curve. Which among the following is a false statement?

options.A: The best investigation is the one whose curve is most upward and left
options.B: The test with the minimum surface area under the cure is the most effective
options.C: Can be used for comparing two or more diagnostic tests
options.D: Can be used for deciding optimal cut-off points

questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) The test with the minimum surface area under the curve is the most effective Explanation: The test with the maximum surface area under its curve is the most effective in the receiver operating curve. The ROC curve illustrates the performance of a diagnostic test by plotting sensitivity (true positive rate) against 1 – specificity (false positive rate) for various threshold values. Two or more diagnostic tests can be compared The best test is the one with the maximum area under its curve, i.e. the most upward and most left curve Can be used for deciding optimal cut-off points Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8831439/

questions.question: Below is a graph showing the results of a screening test. If the cut-off point is reduced from point B to A, what will be its effect on this screening test?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sensitivity increases Explanation: In a screening test, if the cut-off value that differentiates normal and diseased populations is changed from point B to point A on the curve [ie. Value reduced] the test's sensitivity will be increased [i.e. high true positives], but specificity will be reduced [high false positives]. If the cut-off is increased from point A to point B, sensitivity is reduced, and specificity is increased.

questions.question: Screening of syphilis RPR test is done first. All those positive on RPR are submitted to FTA-ABS. Multiple tests were done in parallel. What will be seen ?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: A) Sensitivity increases and specificity decreases. EXPLANATION: When multiple tests are done in parallel, the sensitivity increases and specificity decreases. Tests done in series Tests done in parallel A population is subjected to one screening test followed by a second one. The second test is done only if the first test is positive. Multiple tests are done concurrently. A person is considered positive for disease if any tests give a positive result. Evaluation of screening tests: Tests in series Tests in parallel Sensitivity Decreases Increases Specificity Increases Decreases PPV Increases Decreases NPV Decreases Increases PPV: Positive predictive value, NPV: Negative predictive value. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 156 Medical Biostatistics, 4th edition, Page 56

questions.question: A 40-year-old healthy man visits his family physician for a routine check-up. His physician recommends a series of tests to identify potential diseases that might be present without causing symptoms. This proactive approach is an example of which of the following?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: C) Screening EXPLANATION: Screening: Identifying unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals using rapidly applied tests or other procedures. Purpose: early detection of disease before the person develops signs and symptoms The screening test is applied to the hidden (healthy) portion of the iceberg with the maximum disease burden. Advantages of Screening: Early Detection. Secondary level of prevention Reduce Disease Burden Cost-Effectiveness Public Health Benefit Diagnosis refers to identifying a disease after the patient presents with symptoms or signs of a disease. ( Option A) Surveillance involves continuous, systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health-related data needed for planning, implementing, and evaluating public health practice ( Option B) . Lead time is the period between earliest possible point of diagnosis when there are no signs and symptoms to the usual time of diagnosis (Option C) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 26th Edition Pg: 151-152

questions.question: The diagnostic power of a test to correctly exclude the disease is reflected by?
questions.explanation: test result do not have the disease, reflecting the diagnostic power of a test to exclude disease correctly. It indicates how well a negative test result predicts the absence of the disease. Formula: Negative predictive value = True negative / True negative +False negatives Positive Predictive Value (PPV): It is the probability that individuals with a positive test result truly have the disease or condition of interest. It indicates how well a test result predicts the presence of the disease. Formula: Positive predictive value = True positive / True positives +False positives Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page.155,156 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.133,134

questions.question: Specificity is a property of a screening test .Specificity of a test means all except?

options.A: Refers to the ability of a test to identify those without a condition as negative.
options.B: It is calculated as the ratio of true negatives to the sum of true negatives and false positives.
options.C: A highly specific test will rarely produce false positives.
options.D: It is related to the condition's prevalence in the population being tested.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) It is related to the condition's prevalence in the population being tested. negative rate). It is expressed as the proportion of true negatives (those who do not have the disease) among all disease-free individuals. Specificity is independent of the condition's prevalence in the population being tested. Positive predictive value is directly proportional to prevalence Negative Predictive value is inversely proportional to prevalence Formula: Specificity = True negatives / True negatives + False positives Importance: High specificity is important to minimise the number of false positive results, which can lead to further testing and potentially harmful treatments. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page.155 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine, 2nd edition, Page.134

questions.question: Sensitivity is the ability of a test to detect?

options.A: Individuals who do not have the disease
options.C: Individuals who have the disease but test negative
options.D: Individuals who do not have the disease but test positive

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Individuals who have the disease Explanation: Sensitivity is a test's ability to correctly identify individuals who have the disease (true positive rate). It is expressed as the proportion of true positives (those who have the disease) among all individuals who have the disease. Formula: Importance: High sensitivity is crucial for screening tests to ensure that most diseased individuals are identified and can receive further diagnostic testing or treatment. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page.155 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.134

questions.question: Which of the following is not a test used for assessing accuracy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Scatter Plot Explanation: Scatter plot is used to assess precision. Validity/accuracy refers to the extent to which a measurement or diagnostic tool accurately identifies or measures what it is intended to. It measures accuracy, indicating how well the tool distinguishes between those with a disease or condition and those without it. Importance of accuracy: Correct Diagnosis and Treatment. Public Health Decision-Making. Epidemiological Research. Screening Programs. Components of accuracy: Sensitivity and Specificity. Accuracy tests: Mean chart (Option A). Levy Jenning (LJ) chart (Option B). Shewhart control chart (Option C). Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page.154,155 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine, 2nd edition, Page.134

questions.question: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with chest pain. An ECG is performed. Doctor 1 reviews the ECG and reports it as normal. However, Doctor 2 reviewed the same ECG and reported that it was abnormal. What is the most likely explanation for the differing interpretations of the patient's ECG by Doctor 1 and Doctor 2?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Interobserver variation Explanation: Interobserver variability refers to the differences in interpreting diagnostic tests or clinical findings between observers. This can occur even when both observers are highly trained and using the same diagnostic criteria. Individual judgment, experience, and subjective assessment contribute to this variability. Properties of a screening test: Acceptability. Reliability/reproducibility/repeatability/consistency/precision. Validity/accuracy. Reliability: It refers to the consistency of a measurement or diagnostic test. High reliability means repeated measurements or interpretations by different observers produce similar results. Depends on 3 Factors: Observer Variability Biological Variation Errors Related to Technology Interobserver Variation: Differences between different observers. Example: Two doctors interpret the same ECG differently, which leads to different diagnoses. Natural changes in a patient's physiological parameters over time. For example, blood pressure fluctuates daily, and cholesterol levels vary with diet. Inaccuracies in measurement are due to malfunctioning equipment. For example, a faulty thermometer gives inconsistent temperatures. Intraobserver Variation: Differences in interpretation by the same observer at different times. Example: The same doctor interprets an ECG differently when reviewed at different times. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. 154 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.133,134

questions.question: During the COVID-19 pandemic, airports implemented temperature checks and rapid antigen tests for passengers. This is an example of what type of screening?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: A) Prospective Screening EXPLANATION: Prospective screening is a proactive method to identify and manage health threats, such as COVID-19, at airports to prevent widespread outbreaks and detect infected individuals. Prescriptive Screening (Option B) Prospective Screening (Option A) Done for one's own benefit. Secondary level of prevention. Early diagnosis. Done for other's benefit. The primary level of prevention. Control/ prevention of disease. E.g. Screening neonates for neonatal hypothyroidism Deafness in children Blood glucose testing for diabetes mellitus and gestational diabetes Mammography for breast cancer Pap smear for cervical cancer Visual acuity for refractive errors. E.g. Screening of immigrants for diseases like TB and COVID HIV screening for blood donation HIV screening in ANC cases Health checkups for workers in the food industry. Predictive screening( Option C) , used in genetic disorders, identifies people at high risk of developing a disease in later life. Mass Screening( Option D) is done for an entire population or a subgroup regardless of risk, such as screening all adults over 18 for high blood pressure in public places. Reference: 1. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/predictive-testing 2. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/323457581_Manual_of_screening

questions.question: A health camp was organized to conduct cervical cancer screening in pregnant females. Which of the following best explains this type of screening test?
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) Multiphasic Screening EXPLANATION: Pap smear is a type of multiphasic screening that involves multiple tests, often starting with simple tests followed by more complex ones if initial results indicate a risk. Types of screening tests: 1. Mass Screening (OPTION C) All individuals screened irrespective of high risk. Least efficient type of screening. 2. High-risk screening/ selective screening/ targeted screening (OPTION A) Only high-risk individuals are screened. Most efficient form of screening. E.g.: Hypertension screening in the elderly. TB screening in lower socio-economic population. Breast cancer screening with a family history of breast cancer. 3. Multiphasic screening Application of 2 or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time to detect a single disease. E.g., Health camps for cervical cancer: Questionnaire, Pap smear , Visual inspection. 4. Multipurpose screening (OPTION D) Screen the population with more than one test done simultaneously to detect more than one disease Screening blood tests of pregnant females (Hb, RA, HIV, VDRL, HbsAg) 5. Opportunistic screening or Case-finding Screening conducted during routine healthcare visits for other reasons Presumptive identification was not raised at the patient's request E.g., Screen everyone above 30 for hypertension Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page: 153

questions.question: Which of the following statements about diseases suitable for screening is true? The disease should have a significant impact on public health. Early detection and treatment should reduce morbidity. The disease should have a short latent period. A reliable, invasive, and cost-effective screening test should be available. The disease should have a high prevalence in the population.
questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) 1, 2, and 5 EXPLANATION: Disease criteria suitable for a screening test: The disease should have a significant impact on public health The natural history of the disease should be clearly understood (from the latest phase to the developed disease) Disease should have a prolonged latent phase and high prevalence The test should detect diseases in their early stages in asymptomatic individuals Tests should be reliable, accurate, non-invasive , easy to administer, and cost-effective. The facility should be available to confirm the diagnosis Treatment should be available. Evidence should show that early detection and timely treatment reduce mortality and morbidity. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 26th Edition Pg: 153

questions.question: Which of the following appropriately represents lead time in the given figure
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) B to Y Explanation: Lead time: Time gained by early detection of disease or time difference between the earliest possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis. Lead time bias: Early detection of disease before symptom onset and starting treatment early increases life expectancy; however, it does not make the patient live longer. Arise when no treatment for the disease is available Do not change the prognosis with early diagnosis. (early-stage cancer, if treatment is not available). There is no actual effect on survival, just a longer period with diagnosis. It decreases mortality rates and increases disease prevalence. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Page: 151-152
